this is an exciting new technology that

the ability to among other things
greatly enhance the energy efficiency of

diesels

thanks a lot for having us here Justin
so my father and I started the company
almost 10 years ago and my father's a

graduate work at MIT studying artificial
intelligence and I just kind of started
out by helping him and you know he
looked at the issues of thermodynamics
and looking at your car engine for
example you know you're a typical car
converts about 15% of the energy in the

energy is wasted as heat either out the
exhaust or out the radiator as a
physicist this always just really
bothered him right why are we leaving so
much energy on the table
can't we do better than this so a lot of
people have tried to make better engines
over the years most people focused on
you know mechanisms and kind of just
little changes to how we how angels are
done our approach was fundamentally
different we really started you know
back with the physics of how engines
operate what an engine is really trying
to do how it converts that energy from
the fuel into mechanical work and when
we when we started from the cycle from
the thermodynamics we found a lot of
room for improvement so almost 10 years
ago we started the company we have a new
optimized thermodynamic cycle that we
call the high-efficiency hybrid cycle we
call it that because in some sense what
we're doing is kind of cherry-picking
features from different cycles that
already
exist you know if somebody asks you
what's more efficient a diesel engine or
a gasoline engine it's kind of a trick
question
diesel engines in practice are more
efficient for one reason only because
they get a much higher compression ratio
than gasoline engines but if you look at
the combustion process of a diesel
engine they're actually really
inefficient and the reason for that is
because it takes a long time to inject
mix and burn all of that fuel and while
you're doing all that your your your
piston keeps moving right so your piston
is expanding the volume is increasing
the pressures are dropping due to the
expansion while you're burning the fuel
and those two things kind of fight each
other what we really want to do is do
our combustion under what's called
constant volume conditions an Otto cycle
does that naturally at least the ideal
Otto cycle which is how gasoline engines
are modeled the reason for that is
gasoline engines have a faster
combustion process so more of the
combustion happens while the piston is
near the top dead center position so the
bottom line is we really want to kind of
constrain the combustion process to be
more complete and more thorough before
the piston you know moves away during
the expansion stroke so we can do things
like this on the thermodynamic side and
really improve the efficiency of an
engine by up to two fold over where
gasoline engines are today and the other
thing that we did is when you rethink
the thermodynamics of the engine we have
to completely rethink the entire engine
architecture because what we're trying
to do is pretty much impossible to do
with a piston but with the rotary type
of engine we can play all sorts of
geometric tricks with the engine so that
we could do this new thermodynamic cycle
so what we've developed and we're
currently on our fourth generation of
the engine the very first one by the way
was a true liquid piston whether there
